title: Ping Spikes Galore
body:
For the last two weeks or so, I've been having tremendous lag, which is super out of character for my connection.

The best I can describe it:
Takes at least a full 3 seconds before getting into champion select, maximum has been around 10-15 seconds.
Takes at least 5 minutes to load into every game. Takes a long time for the loading screen to even show up. In rarer cases the game will start without me. I recently loaded into a game just to watch the Defeat explode onto my screen from the remake.
In game, Constant ping spikes anywhere between 100-250 every couple seconds. Some times it will get worse and completely disconnect me from the game.

I used to play with solid 30 ping, what the hell is going on? I can't even play the game anymore!

I've run hextech repair tool probably 3 times a day, changing the settings each time for the last 2 weeks as administrator. A few days ago, I stopped lagging for about 12 hours after using it, but I think it was more or less a coincidence.

I just want to play league of legends ;-;

replies.body:
Changes in latency (ping) are often caused by network routing by your ISP. Before we take an in-depth look at your routing to the server, I'd like you to confirm your local network settings are compatible with League by following our [connection guide.](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues)

Let me know if those steps caused any positive change.
No luck, however I'm starting to think my internet is the problem

If those local changes caused no change, then this is likely caused by problems along your route to the server. I'd like you to run a traceroute log using [**WinMTR**](http://winmtr.net/), a really useful network application. After opening the app, simply plug in **104.160.131.1** into the host field and start the trace. After it's run for about 5 minutes or longer, export the results as text and paste them in a reply to me.

Let me know if you have any issues completing this log.

Your latency spikes start *within your home network* then continue along your route until the last hop before reaching out servers. I strongly recommend reaching out to a tier 2 support rep at your ISP that can take a look at this traceroute and work with you to resolve this.

Let me know if you have any other questions.
I'll look into it, thank you for your time Targon, I really do appreciate it ^^ {{item:2052}}
